text:
About [imath]\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{5},\sqrt[3]{7})[/imath]

Let [imath]K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{5},\sqrt[3]{7})\subset \mathbb{C}[/imath]. To compute [imath][K:\mathbb{Q}][/imath], I know that 
\begin{align*}
[\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{5}):\mathbb{Q}]&=2\\
[\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt[3]{7}):\mathbb{Q}]&=3.
\end{align*}
Can I say that [imath]2<[K:\mathbb{Q}]\leq 6[/imath] and because [imath]2\not |[/imath] [imath]3,5[/imath] and [imath]3\not | [/imath] [imath]4[/imath], then [imath][K:\mathbb{Q}]=6[/imath]?
And, if [imath]\gamma=\sqrt{5}\sqrt[3]{7}[/imath], the minimal polynomial of [imath]\gamma[/imath] over [imath]\mathbb{Q}(\gamma)[/imath] would be [imath]p(x)=x^6-5^37^2?[/imath]
I'm a bit insecure about this.
Thanks in advance.


If [imath]K=\Bbb Q(\sqrt5,\sqrt[3]7)[/imath] then [imath]|K:\Bbb Q|=|K:\Bbb Q(\sqrt5)|
|\Bbb Q(\sqrt5):\Bbb Q|[/imath] so [imath]|K:\Bbb Q|[/imath] is divisible by [imath]2[/imath].
Similarly [imath]|K:\Bbb Q|[/imath] is divisible by [imath]3[/imath] (why?). So
it is divisible by [imath]6[/imath] (as [imath]2[/imath] and [imath]3[/imath] are coprime). But [imath]|K:\Bbb Q|\le 6[/imath]
(why?).

If [imath]|K:Q|>6[/imath], then the minimal polynomial can't have degree 6?
@Nico that's one way to see it.
